msContents.summary: An early example of a Book of Hours produced in Bruges for the English market. The Calendar lists Sts Donatian, Judoc, Basil and Eligius and the Litany includes 'S. Gheertrudis'. A London or Essex provenance is suggested by the memoria of St Ethelburga added in the early 15th century (16v). The miniatures were painted by the Master of the Beaufort Saints.

msItem.title: Suffrage to the Holy Trinity
msItem.note: 'Domine deus omnipotens pater et filius et spiritus sanctus da mihi famulo tuo'

msItem.title: Suffrage to the Holy Face
msItem.note: Antiphon (Repertorium Hymnologicum 18189) and prayer 'Deus qui nobis signati lumine'

msItem.title: Suffrage to St John the Baptist
msItem.note: Antiphon (RH 26987) and prayer 'Beate iohannes baptista christi precursor'

msItem.title: Suffrage to St Thomas of Canterbury
msItem.note: Antiphon (RH 26999) and prayer 'Deus qui beatum Thomam martyrem tuum atque pontificem'

msItem.title: Suffrage to St Christopher
msItem.note: Antiphon (RH 39618) and prayer 'Concede quaesumus omnipotens et misericors deus ut qui beati christofori'

msItem.title: Suffrage to St Catherine
msItem.note: Antiphon (RH 6993) and prayer 'Deus qui dedisti legem Moysi'

msItem.title: Suffrage to St Mary Magdalene
msItem.note: Antiphon (RH 6895) and prayer 'Deus qui beate marie magdalene penitentiam tibi placitam'

msItem.title: Hymns and prayers to the Virgin
msItem.note: Hymn (RH 18310?); prayers 'Deus qui de beate marie virginis', 'O intemerata', and 'Obsecro te'; seven prayers in honour of the Virgin, with an indulgence for remission of a hundred days in the name of Pope Clement (RH 21899); final prayer 'Te deprecor sanctissima maria'.

msItem.title: Hymns on the Passion of Christ
msItem.author: Johannes, Lemovicensis, active 13th century

msItem.title: Prayer
msItem.note: 'Omnipotens sempiterne deus qui unigenitum filium tuum'

msItem.title: The Seven Last Words of the Lord
msItem.author: Bede, the Venerable, Saint, 673-735
msItem.title: De septem verbis Christi
msItem.rubric: 62v Oratio venerabilis bede presbiteri de septem verbis christi in cruce pendentis
msItem.incipit: 70v Domine ihesu christe qui septem verba die ultimo vite tue

msItem.title: Prayers to Christ and the body of Christ
Hymns and prayers
msItem.note: Prayer 'Domine ihesu christe qui hora diei ultima de crucis depositus'; hymn (RH 1974); prayers 'Omnipotens sempiterne deus qui gloriose virginis marie' and 'Sancta et perpetua virgo maria'; kyrieleison; prayers 'Deprecor ergo te piissima dei genitrix', 'O domina dulcissima pia', 'Dominus rex omnium ex te nobis fecit', 'Gaude virgo gaudium maria', 'Deus qui beatam virginem et matrem maria'.

supportDesc.foliation: Modern pencil foliation in the top right corner of each leaf.

collation.p: The manuscript consists of 16 quires, mostly gatherings of 8 leaves and occasionally with miniatures inserted on additional single leaves. Quire 2 comprises numerous single leaves and its collation is irregular; the exact structure of the quire is uncertain. The structure of Quire 13 is also not clear. According to Binski and Zutshi, a miniature of St Jerome has been removed before 135r at the beginning of Quire 16, however it has not been possible to determine how this related to the collation of the volume.

list.item: Quire 98+2 (fols 73-82; 1st and 2nd leaves inserted before f. 75)

condition.p: Staining to the opening endleaves (1r-3v) and occasional moisture-damage (16r-16v, 131r).
Most of the miniatures have been heavily rubbed and their pigments have flaked away (10v, 12v, 14v, 17v, 19v, 21v, 23v, 98v, 109v, 126v).
A few initials have been smudged (8v-9r, 92r).
Suffrages to St Thomas of Canterbury have been crossed out roughly (16r-16v, 36r).

layout.p: Single column, 21 lines, ruled in red ink, below top line.
Calendar: single column, 34 lines, ruled in red ink, below top line.

decoNote.p:
Thirteen (originally fifteen) full-page miniatures, framed by green, blue, orange, ochre or pink panels linked by gold quadrilobes and surrounded by short black sprays terminating in gold disks and ivy leaves.
10v: Throne of Mercy ('Domine deus omnipotens')
12v: Vernicle ('Salve sancta facies')
14v: St John the Baptist ('Gaude Iohannes Baptista')
[before 16r: ?St Thomas of Canterbury; miniature removed ('Gaude lux londaniarum')]
17v: St Christopher ('Sancte Cristofore')
19v: St Catherine ('Gaude virgo Katherina')
21v: St Mary Magdalene ('Gaude pia magdalena')
23v: Annunciation (Matins of the Virgin)
51v: Our Lady of Humility ('Salve virgo virginum')
74v: Deposition (Hours of the Passion)
91v: Man of Sorrows (Psalms of the Passion)
98v: Last Judgement (Penitential Psalms)
109v: funeral service (Office of the Dead)
126v: Christ holding or blessing three souls carried to heaven by two angels ('Commendatio animarum')
[before 135r: ?St Jerome; miniature removed ('Beatus ieronimus')]

Twenty-one three- to six-line initials with white ornamentation and blue, purple and orange floral scroll infill on burnished gold ground. At major textual divisions, initials are accompanied by four-sided frames of cusped burnished gold, purple and blue bars with short oak and ivy leaf scrolls and gold studded black sprays. At minor textual divisions, there are identical bars extending from purple-and-orange initials in the left-hand margins.
24r, 28v, 39r, 41r, 42v, 44r, 45v, 46v: Hours of the Virgin.
52r: 'Salve virgo virginum'.
75r, 77v, 78v, 79v, 80v, 81v, 82v: Hours of the Passion.
92r: Psalm 22.
99r: Penitential Psalms.
110r: Office of the Dead.
127r: 'Commendatio animarum'.
135r: Psalter of St Jerome.

Two- and three-line burnished gold initials with blue/purple infill and frames, to verses, prayers and in the Calendar. With gold, blue and purple bars with white patterns and short gold-studded black sprays extending from gold initials in left margins.
One- and two-line blue or gold initials with red or purple flourishes.

additions.p: Computus texts and prayers added to endleaves and blank spaces within the manuscript, in Latin and Middle English. One of the additions, made in the early 15th century, is a memoria to St Ethelburga (16v).

history.provenance: John Moore, Bishop of Ely (1646-1714) Moore, John, 1646-1714 . Presented to the University Library by King George I George I, King of Great Britain, 1660-1727 in 1715.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card for admissions procedures contact Cambridge University Library Admissions). Contact the Manuscripts Department for further information on the availability of this manuscript
